Has anyone used the following python packages to collect horse racing data: <https://pypi.org/user/justjasongreen/>? Is it useful? If you look at the racing data package it seems to contain some really useful information for creating predictive models. It uses something called MongoDB, I have no experience of this, does anyone else? I have been trying to get it working this morning without any luck.

elements.text: Have you read this?

text: I understand that it is a mechanism for determining the starting odds of an event, however, I do not understand the bigger picture:  are those markets separated from the rest of the markets, is there a particular interval of time (e.g. first hour of trading) in which the SP is determined...and the like

elements.text: I understand that it is a mechanism for determining the starting odds of an event, however, I do not understand the bigger picture:  are those markets separated from the rest of the markets, is there a particular interval of time (e.g. first hour of trading) in which the SP is determined...and the like

text: They are not entirely separate because the BSP liability may be matched with standard orders on the exchange if there is not enough liquidity on either side

elements.text: They are not entirely separate because the BSP liability may be matched with standard orders on the exchange if there is not enough liquidity on either side

text: The BSP is determined at the moment the market turns in play

elements.text: The BSP is determined at the moment the market turns in play

text: You can bet at BSP at any time up until it turns in play

elements.text: You can bet at BSP at any time up until it turns in play

text: I see, thanks a lot Mo. So it seems the orders that do not match in the BSP betting phase could potentially be matched when the market turns in play, so really there isn't much difference between betting for the BSP or betting once the market turns in play? other than the chance of being able to bet sooner

elements.text: I see, thanks a lot Mo. So it seems the orders that do not match in the BSP betting phase could potentially be matched when the market turns in play, so really there isn't much difference between betting for the BSP or betting once the market turns in play? other than the chance of being able to bet sooner

text: There's a big difference between the two. If you are placing a BSP bet you are influencing what the BSP is unlike if you wait until BSP reconciliation. There's also no guarantee that there will be prices available to bet at the BSP price once it's been determined

elements.text: There's a big difference between the two. If you are placing a BSP bet you are influencing what the BSP is unlike if you wait until BSP reconciliation. There's also no guarantee that there will be prices available to bet at the BSP price once it's been determined

text: <@UBS7QANF3> looking at this package when I call "date = datetime(2016, 12, 1); meets = provider.get_meets_by_date(date)". It returns an empty list. Therefore I am not sure this is maintained. Or it could be something to do with the MongoDB which I do not understand. Looking at MongoDB it is a database system. Though do you know if it is stored locally and set up by yourself or externally and I am merely calling the data? There is also scraper part of this package which makes me think it is stored locally.

text: I use Heroku. It is easy to set up, free and you can choose your ip location. You def have less functionalities than AWS but I guess it is the trade off between easy/simple vs complex/bestinclass service.

elements.text: I use Heroku. It is easy to set up, free and you can choose your ip location. You def have less functionalities than AWS but I guess it is the trade off between easy/simple vs complex/bestinclass service.

text: <@U014W8KJGNL> From a quick look it looks to be using a local mongo db, it is referencing <https://pypi.org/project/punters-client/> which looks to be a scraper, which scrapes <http://www.punters.com.au|www.punters.com.au> so I think the suggested workflow of these packages is to use that package to scrape the data into mongo and then use racing-data/predictive-punter to analyse/interrogate that data, I'd bear in mind these packages were written 4 years ago too, so the scraping may not still work there

text: <@UFPEU7URG> ye I was thinking along these lines. In terms of data collection have you used the Betfair timeform data. I had a quick look and it appears to have good data for predictive modeling. Here’s a link to it <https://developer.betfair.com/en/get-started/#timeform-api|https://developer.betfair.com/en/get-started/#timeform-api>. Though the associated documentation is not available and it is also £500 per month.

attachments.title: The Beginner's Guide to Betfair Developer Tools
attachments.text: Get started by choosing the right API for your application and the right licence. We'll connect you to the right people at Betfair.
attachments.fallback: The Beginner's Guide to Betfair Developer Tools

text: on that same topic, to those that have strategies in production, does it happen often that you see a price available that you want, and when you go take it, it is already gone?
